text: We will be adding additional information to this overview in the near future. Remember that testing supplies remain limited and this is not a complete picture of the presence of COVID-19 statewide. #StayHomeStaySafe  https://t.co/6Tl2r9yc1v https://t.co/2Cd8bTZOhn

The Wyoming Department of Health is supporting a CDC recommendation to wear cloth face coverings if you need to go out in the community in order to help slow the spread of COVID-19. This is not a replacement for social distancing. Guidelines here: https://t.co/xjexhwMh35

Our Unemployment Office is working quickly to implement expanded benefits available under the CARES Act. These include an extension of regular unemployment, additional funding for those eligible, and the expansion of benefits for self-employed or contract employees. https://t.co/7Tm6qMQqWB

Wyoming recorded it's 200th confirmed case of COVID-19 today, but we know that there are many more untested Wyomingites who have the virus. Keep yourself and your family safe and our healthcare workers protected by staying home and social distancing. #StayHomeStayHealthy https://t.co/Ubl9IBo9hp
The First Lady and I want you to know what we're doing to keep our people safe and our communities functioning as best they can during these challenging times. https://t.co/RJrrvn9PMC

Lincoln County has its first confirmed case. With warming temperatures this weekend, it's important to remember to stay vigilant and keep your distance as you enjoy some fresh air. #staysafe https://t.co/Zg0ySqRLAQ
Now is not the time to travel to Wyoming. We are focused on protect the health of our citizens and the resources of our rural healthcare facilities. Stay home and stay safe. https://t.co/qBcqZGCc6W

I have also issued a directive requiring any individual coming to Wyoming for a non-work-related purpose to immediately self-quarantine for 14 days. Visitors from neighboring states have strained the resources of our communities and put public health at risk.

I have extended the three existing statewide health orders through April 30 to slow community transmission of COVID-19. I want to be perfectly clear- we want all Wyoming residents to stay at home. Our focus is on improving compliance and adherence. That is how we will save lives.

At 3 p.m. today, April 3, I am holding a press conference to provide an update on Wyoming's response to COVID-19 and outline what we are doing next to keep Wyomingites safe. You can watch here on Facebook or on Youtube at https://t.co/5QQODg9sNb. https://t.co/H7nbDNT9yP

We continue to monitor the spread of COVID-19 closely and now have confirmed cases in 16 Wyoming counties as well as additional recovered cases. By staying home and avoiding gatherings, we can #SlowTheSpread and save lives. https://t.co/vZ2BTruhfF

Please note, the number of tests does not include all negative results from private laboratories. COVID-19 will continue to spread and doesn't discriminate according to age or overall health. But we know staying home and social distancing will help #SlowTheSpread https://t.co/ALqFAY0fkY

I signed a proclamation declaring today #CensusDay Now more than ever, it's critical that each of us in Wyoming is counted. Census results help determine how billions of dollars in funding flow into Wyoming communities each year. https://t.co/BE7EnyTLF1. https://t.co/shsyaTbZgo

It's #CensusDay2020! While staying at home today, I encourage each of you to respond and ensure we get an accurate count. 
Census results help determine how billions of dollars in federal funding flow into Wyoming communities each year. https://t.co/rzj18gpCOS https://t.co/LhKuAmk1c0

As we see more confirmed cases, its critical we continue to limit public contact as much as possible. Your actions don't just impact you, they impact the people around you.  Thank you to all Wyomingites who are doing your part. #StayHomeStaySafe https://t.co/K4VdquMNVz

I took questions and heard your concerns about #COVID19 during an @AARPWY TeleTown Hall today.  I'm grateful that so many of our state's older residents are so engaged on this critical issue. https://t.co/80Z7fiCXPm
▶️We have updated info on https://t.co/eRcuaJGPqQ including an FAQ for Wyoming citizens and additional links to resources developed from our 5 COVID-19 task forces. #StayHome
We will continue to closely monitor the operations of our state parks to ensure visitor safety, and may take additional action if our health officials deem it necessary. https://t.co/Yg0ENQuo2F

#COVID19 case numbers have tripled in a week, a result of both increased testing and increased disease. The public health orders and social distancing measures we've put in place will help, if they are followed. It's up to you Wyoming- together, we can #slowthespread https://t.co/HmGtayXGEl
In an hour (3:30 pm), I will hold a media briefing to provide updates on Wyoming's #COVID19 response. Watch live on the @WyomingPBS Facebook page or on YouTube https://t.co/keBQfdkNEq
Thank you to these volunteers and others around the state who are stepping up to support our healthcare workers. https://t.co/VyFVNQOuGm

Additional collection kits were distributed last week, but testing is still limited nationally and in Wyoming. It's important for Wyomingites to understand this is not a complete picture of the prevalence of COVID-19 in our state. Stay safe, stay home, practice #SocialDistancing https://t.co/bvu5ebqAwI

It's critical we limit person-to-person contact over the coming weeks. Extended families need to practice #socialdistancing as well. Delay gatherings with extended family. If you are delivering food or supplies to loved ones, you can protect them by staying 6 feet apart. https://t.co/nE5ZW3O4c5
The First Lady and I want to talk with you about how social distancing and staying home is going to help save lives. We're all in this together, Wyoming. https://t.co/Efwscdabb0

We are continuing to see more test results return and a corresponding rise in the number of confirmed cases. Help #SlowTheSpread  by staying home whenever possible. For county-by-county statistics visit https://t.co/6Tl2r9yc1v https://t.co/Q4t0DJikCm
RT @WyoBizCouncil: #Wyoming @GovernorGordon just announced "Layoff Aversion Grants" to help avert or shorten layoffs during the #covid19 ou…

This is how we can save lives and protect people’s health.  I also understand the ongoing strain these measures are having on businesses, workers and Wyoming communities but it is critical each of us takes these steps now.

I am extending the three statewide health orders through April 17 to #slowthespread of community transmission of COVID-19. It is imperative we all respond to this public health crisis by staying home whenever possible and practicing proper social distancing when they must go out.

The number of counties with confirmed cases has increased, a reminder that COVID-19 will impact all of us. Staying home whenever possible is the best way to #SlowTheSpread We have added data on recovered cases to this graphic. https://t.co/sPkHPxF2Sz

Grocery stores are an essential service that won't close. Keep in mind, #socialdistancing matters when shopping, too. Give your neighbors space and don't go out if you are sick. Actions like these help #slowthespread. #COVID19WY https://t.co/6lnrkuyS7x
I applaud this decision, as well as the cooperation of the utility companies, for working together to help Wyoming's people during this difficult time. https://t.co/mQ0ilOt5MX

As our state's testing capacity expands and more results come in from commercial labs, we expect confirmed cases to rise. The steps we are urging all Wyomingites to take– staying home and practicing social distancing – are what will help mitigate the impacts in the weeks to come. https://t.co/9P00wex1Cz

Now is not the time to be evicting individuals who may have recently become unemployed. It’s important for us all to work together and support one-another during these difficult times. If you are struggling, Wyoming 211 has a list of statewide resources. https://t.co/Z1IUKXVeCI

I have been contacted by many constituents who are concerned that they may be facing eviction proceedings as the end of the month approaches. I urge our state’s landlords to exercise maximum flexibility with your tenants when it comes to rent payments.

I urge our citizens to stay home whenever possible and go out only when absolutely necessary. This will help Wyoming #SlowtheSpread of COVID-19 and #FlattenTheCurve Your voluntary actions and discipline will make the difference for you, your family and your neighbors. #COVID19WY https://t.co/hfAAD7JBb6
RT @WyomingPBS: REMINDER: 1p. @GovernorGordon news conference streamed live from @WyomingPBS Here is the link: https://t.co/392e8bqTEd #wyl…

The number of confirmed cases continues to grow. Tomorrow, March 24 at 1 p.m. I will be joined by the First Lady and state leaders to share how we can work together to help one another and #SlowTheSpread Watch live on the @WyomingPBS  Facebook page and YouTube channel. #COVID19WY https://t.co/VkiJCQNPED

I understand the impact of these measures and sympathize with those most affected, especially small business owners, but this is about saving lives. We have tried to navigate a thoughtful course, but as COVID-19 spreads through our communities, we must take this action now.

Wyoming is taking further steps to #slowthespread of #COVID19WY. Today, we issued an order to temporarily close nail salons; hair salons; barber shops; massage parlors; tattoo, body art, piercing shops; and cosmetology, electrology, and esthetic services until April 3.

Helping your neighbor is the WY way. WY distilleries are banding together to make hand sanitizer to help #slowthespread of #COVID19.  Supplies for these innovative efforts are paid for through Imminent Threat Grants from the @WyoBizCouncil https://t.co/fhHuUnqvoy https://t.co/9HgrTNPmMo

We have confirmed two additional cases of COVID-19 in the state today. Viruses don't respect county boundaries- the best way to #SlowTheSpread is staying home whenever possible, working from home if it's feasible and limiting our trips out. #COVID19WY https://t.co/12R0Ud38XC

We are at a critical time for our state. There are unquestionably more cases out there. Thank you to all Wyomingites who are practicing social distancing. 
Limit travel and stay home if possible. 
Wash hands frequently. #COVID19WY https://t.co/2HJrJKQrIt

Testing will continue to expand statewide, so we can expect the number of confirmed cases to increase. Please practice good hygiene and social distancing measures to #SlowTheSpread #COVID19WY https://t.co/jUZLAXo1Ge

9/9 Shop for groceries if you need to, get food delivered from your favorite restaurant, support your local business with a gift card purchase. But please practice social distancing measures during this critical time. #COVID19WY

8/9 By limiting travel and face-to-face contact now, we reduce the potential to overwhelm our rural healthcare facilities and cause unnecessary deaths ahead. Wyoming’s rural nature does not protect us from impacts.
7/9 Like the rest of America, Wyoming’s access to testing supplies is limited. Our best tool right now for slowing the spread of this disease is practicing social distancing measures.

6/9 ...the enormity of the public health challenge facing us and respond to it. COVID-19 may seem far away, but it is here. Our neighboring states are all experiencing the same escalation in the number of positive cases as we are.

5/9 I am a businessman and understand full well what the consequences would be of closures. I know that the worst impacts would fall on those least able to absorb it.   As confirmed cases have grown from 1 to 23 in a week, spanning 8 counties, we should be honest about...

4/9 ...that unemployment benefits are readily accessible, that those who are food insecure are fed, and that our essential business functions are preserved. I am proud of my Wyoming heritage and the fact that we can serve as a beacon for our nation.

3/9 We are in this for the long haul and we will emerge stronger for this test, and I will always be guided by my concern for the health and safety of the people of Wyoming. folks at the state are working 24/7 to assure that proper supplies arrive as quickly as possible...

2/9 From the beginning, I have emphasized that the challenge we are facing represents two threats: disease and economic harm.  I have been very clear that both are important.  I believe firmly we must do the right thing, do it right away, and do it the right way.

1/9 The coronavirus is the most disruptive thing that most of us have ever seen.  I recognize and appreciate the criticism from some that we have not acted rapidly, and I appreciate and recognize the criticism that we have acted too much. #COVID19WY

Excellent news: Wyoming small businesses impacted by COVID-19 have received final Federal approval to seek loans up to $2 million as part of the SBA’s Economic Injury Disaster Loan program. To apply visit: https://t.co/o5lyRxovgZ #COVID19WY

Yesterday's closure order only impacts certain types of businesses. Included in the list are restaurants, bars, gyms, movie theaters, music halls and day cares. Other private businesses are not required to close. Social distancing is our best weapon to #StopTheSpread #COVID19WY https://t.co/D3zvG81GuL

I have endorsed an order from our state health officer closing public places for a period of 2 weeks to help slow the spread of COVID-19. It is a critical step for protecting public health and the health of our most vulnerable residents. https://t.co/Z8617fwG3Y

It's time for Wyomingites to do all we can to slow the spread of COVID-19 in the state. Following the @POTUS social distancing guidelines will benefit all of us, particularly our health care providers and vulnerable populations. #covid19WY https://t.co/77dCaZl4OT

3/4 Although absolutely necessary, I recognize the toll these measures will take on those most dependent on a working wage. But by working together and practicing good hygiene, kindness and charity, we can keep vulnerable adults healthy...

2/4 We should use good judgment, avoid unnecessary travel, keep social gatherings to groups of fewer than 10 people, and use drive-through, pickup or delivery options from our local restaurants. These are going to be perhaps the toughest times any of us will see in our lifetimes. https://t.co/8ruNwKLssX

This is Wyoming, where we are all neighbors. While social distancing should be a priority, it should not keep us from helping one another out. I am thinking of our first responders and healthcare workers  who may be without child care. This is a time to help one another out.
This is an attempt to allow schools and communities to prepare to operate in a way that mitigates community spread of COVID-19 and minimizes negative economic impacts locally and statewide.

In conjuction with @jillian4supt i have recommended that all schools remain closed to students through at least April 3. Local superintendents and school boards will make the final decisions on closures.

Please know that close coordination is ongoing between the Department of Health, Office of Homeland Security and my office. Our response is based on the best available information, and we will be continually adjusting to what is a rapidly changing situation.

In response, our state health officer has issued recommendations for assisted living facilities that match restrictive guidelines the federal government has issued for nursing homes. These include no visitors or non-essential healthcare personnel. https://t.co/I5EB31bJVZ

Initial follow-up with this individual indicated potential community spread of this virus in the Lander area. Wyoming Department of Health staff will be available to consult as local officials consider decisions about public events and other community-related activities.

I want to provide some updated information on the Fremont County case of #COVIDー19 that was identified yesterday. The patient is hospitalized at SageWest Health Care in Lander and is a resident of Showboat Retirement Center in Lander.

Wyoming has confirmed the second known case of COVID-19 in the state. The patient is a hospitalized older adult male Fremont County resident with currently unknown exposure risk. We will be sharing additional information as it becomes available. https://t.co/TuYxEiSCZS
I will be hosting a press conference on the states response to the first COVID-19 case. It will be streamed on my Facebook page.

The current risk of transmission in Wyoming remains low for most residents. Our Health Department is following up to learn more details about the person’s exposure risk and to identify anyone who may have been in close contact with the patient. https://t.co/jVhlktazEf

Our state has been planning for this situation for weeks and we will continue our coordinated efforts to address this threat. We will continue to work closely with our state agencies, federal partners and local officials to implement all necessary steps to protect public health.

Our state health lab has identified the first known case of a state resident with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). The individual is an adult female from Sheridan County with some recent domestic travel history.

Older adults and those with underlying chronic illnesses are most at risk of severe COVID-19 illness. Wyoming is continuing to prepare and working to protect public health in the event cases appear within our state. For more information, visit https://t.co/phCWwiLBt5

Earlier today I joined the nations governors and @VP for a weekly phone call to hear the latest updates from the @CDCgov . While Wyoming still has no confirmed cases of COVID-19 it’s likely the disease will spread to our state at some point. We are preparing for that likelihood.

This afternoon I joined Wyoming Dept. of Health officials for a conference call with long term care and nursing facilities to ensure proper protocols and preventative measures are in place to protect residents of these facilities from #coronavirus. https://t.co/bipybCNnoN

I'm pleased to welcome Ed Seidel as the new University of Wyoming president. Ed has demonstrated visionary leadership and brings a strong focus on economic development. His exceptional technical and scientific background will benefit the research efforts at UW.

The ports of the United States of America are for all the commerce of the United States of America. We stand today to ensure reasonable access to that foreign trade for all of Wyoming’s and Montana’s products and those of the other states without access to ports.

A de facto blockade limiting the citizens of any state to participate in interstate and international commerce cannot be arbitrarily imposed by another. Congress has the sole authority to regulate trade.

This is an effort to protect all the rights of states as guaranteed under the Constitution -- all rights including those that pertain to commerce.  It is neither a political battle nor an attempt to ride roughshod over the legitimate rights of states to manage their own affairs

Our Constitution was written to ensure that interior states have access to foreign markets through our coastal sister states. Today we are defending Wyoming’s and Montana’s right to utilize American port and rail infrastructure for its products.
I did not make this decision rashly or lightly– vital state and economic interests are at stake. This case is about the right of states to conduct commerce, a question as old as our Constitution.

This morning, in a joint filing with the State of Montana, Wyoming has asked the Supreme Court of the United States to review the decision by the state of Washington to deny the Millennium Bulk coal terminal permit.
https://t.co/VyIvsmt7Zx

I'm pleased that the Senate has approved the #USMCA trade agreement. This is a win for Wyoming's farmers and ranchers and will help boost export sales for businesses in our state.
